There's a marked difference in the planes from the interior displays to the exterior and while I understand the weather can be hard on them, it would be nice to see the larger outdoor exhibits better cared for.
I enjoyed the visit and had a good time explaining the history surrounding the planes to my kids, but it may be some time before I return.
Being an Air Force brat and seeing lots of places. This is in the top 3 in the nation. #1 being the Air Force Museum in Dayton. The next one may be this or the annex for the Smithsonian

For anyone interested in the history of flight, this is a great place to spend an afternoon. They even have an SR71C Blackbird - the only one of its type ever made, and it has a rude nickname.
Once or twice a year they have events where you (or your grandkids) can sit in the cockpits of some of the planes. Busy days, but worth it.
The museum itself is in two parts; an outdoor area where the *really* big planes are, and the indoor area, which is mainly fighters and helicopters. I recommend you try to go during the spring/summer, when the weather is nice enough to wander outside.
Highly recommended.
What a great find. The volunteers were knowledgeable and friendly. Great exhibits and history. Well worth spending an afternoon or morning

We took our children and grandchildren there for a visit. Everyone loved it and thought the displays of memorabilia, planes, and exhibits were very informative and interesting. It was in July, but the rooms were kept cool and comfortable for the many visitors. I would love to go back and see more someday!
_source.review_title: A wonderful place to learn some important history.

_source.comment: Good price and very interesting for kids! Nice to visit in the summer months when the weather is warm! You can get great pictures!

Took my boys ages 7 and 5. We started outside where you could walk around and look at the different types of planes. Some were so huge and it was crazy to be standing right next to them and seeing how small you are in comparison. The boys loved it! The only thing they were disappointed with is the fact that they couldn't go inside any of them. There are a lot of them and it can be quite a walk, so bring some water if it's a hot day. They have paved sidewalks all throughout, so you can bring strollers or wagons for little ones. We then went inside the museum building where there is a small gift shop and a room with other planes and other things to look at. They had replicas of nuclear bombs which was fascinating to see. It opened up opportunities to talk to my kids about war and the men and women that serve our country and protect our freedom. There is no admission fee to see any of this, but they have places where you can put in donations to help with the upkeep of this attraction. They also have volunteers there to answer any of your questions. Was a fun morning and would highly recommend.
_source.review_title: Standing next to those big planes is amazing!

_source.comment: We took our young grandchildren, ages 4 & 7, to see the museum after our grandson spotted the outdoor plane exhibit from I-15. We started with the two indoor exhibit halls, then went outside to see the planes around the grounds. There were easily more adults there than children, so don't be put off if you're traveling without kids. The museum is free, the gift shop offers a nice selection of airplane-related gifts, and there are bathrooms in the main building. If you're planning to stay a while, especially in the summer, pack cold drinks as there are none sold in the store and the only soda machine outside was out of service. As a bonus, the outdoor area offers a great view of the Wasatch Mountains. Oddly, the elderly museum volunteers were cranky on the day we visited. Overall, we had a good time.
It's free!!! Its FUN and its great for all ages. It has a lot of fun facts that you may or may not know about planes, war, military. Kids love it, and adults do too!!!
_source.review_title: A Must see in the Top of Utah

_source.comment: Hill Aerospace Museum is one of the must see places for our grandchildren when they visit every summer. Seeing the planes up close and reading the related history gives them hours of entertainment while learning about this branch of our country's military and their service to the country.

I've lived in this area for over 15 years and had never visited this museum until this summer. I must say, I was shocked at the size of the buildings and the amount of planes on display. Everything was very close up and labeled so that you knew what it was. The museum is nicely laid out and there are even mannequins in period costumes around some of the exhibits. The thing I found most interesting, oddly enough, wasn't a plane, it was a display on Vietnam POWs. They had a replica of a cell at the Hanoi Hilton, along with stories of men who'd served at Hill Air Force Base before (or since) being captured in Vietnam. It was a very interesting story and I enjoyed the way that display was set up very much. I'm not sure I'd give this an overly enthusiastic recommendation for children. My daughter (10) was entertained for about an hour, but after that, she was wanting to leave.

The Hill Aerospace Museum is located on approximately 30 acres on the northwest corner of Hill Air Force Base, about five miles south of Ogden. The museum was founded in 1981 as a part of the United States Air Force Heritage Program and first opened in 1986. It moved to its current facility in 1991.
The Museum exhibits more than 90 military aircraft, missiles, and aerospace vehicles on the grounds and inside the Major General Rex A. Hadley Gallery and the Lindquist Stewart Fighter Gallery.
The list of aircraft on display is extensive. The collection also includes a wide variety of ordnance and munitions, an assortment of aerospace ground equipment, rockets, military vehicles, uniforms, and thousands of other historical artifacts.
We highly recommend a visit to the museum for aviation enthusiasts, and anyone with an interest in vintage aircraft and the United States Air Force history. It truly is an incredible facility well worth visiting.
It is conveniently located just off I-15 at Exit 338, Roy Exit. A gate pass onto Hill AFB is NOT required to visit the museum. Simply take Exit 338 (east) off Interstate 15 in Roy, Utah, and enter the museum grounds through the gate.
Also housed in the museum is an extensive, well-stocked gift shop. Food service is not provided onsite.
Parking and admission is free.
On our last visit in May of 2013, we spent nearly three hours in the museum. But the exhibits are so extensive and well done, that one could easily spend an entire day, and not see everything.

I visit aircraft museums whenever available in each city we travel to during our summer Odysseys. This is one of the finer displays of aircraft in the intermountain west. Very well done with an abundance of volunteers to assist with any questions that may arise. Well worth the visit.

If you are a lover of aircraft, this is the museum for you. Situated at the periphery of Hill Air Force Base in Layton, Utah, this museum has an extensive collection of aircraft, starting with earliest flights until late 20th century. The planes are arranged in chronological order and many are accompanied by recorded descriptions, photos and videos. The entrance fees are low, and during the summer several free days are available. Our young grandsons enjoyed this museum.
_source.review_title: Excellent collection of vintage air raft

_source.comment:
We were very surprised to find such an excellent museum in a small town in Utah, even one near a major Air Force Base.
The museum displays an array of aircraft spanning the history of Air Force, from its origins as the Army Air Corps in WWII to the present, from a B17 to a SR71Blackbird, one of the few on display anywhere.
In addition to planes, there are a number of informative exhibits featuring period specific uniforms and other information about the history of aviation.
This gem of a museum was a pleasant discovery and a great way to spend a morning or an afternoon in Layton. You will learn a lot about history and come away with a greater respect for the men and women who have served our nation over the years.

I took my boys, along with the Scouts to the museum last summer and we all loved it. From the bombers and jets outside, to the fantastic items inside. I loved the old bi-planes and my favorite - the B-17! I think that the boys would have loved to stay longer, but we could only stay for 3 hours before we had to head back. Even then I think we saw more than enough. I think that a few trips would be very worthwhile - especially for anyone who has a love of historical and military aircraft.
I remember my first visit as a scout, where our scoutmaster took us up to a F-4 Phantom and proceeded to tell us stories of his time flying them in 'Nam'. Our recent experience was led by a volunteer from the airbase who was being deployed the next day. He was an actual pilot and the boys loved to hear him talk of his experiences.
We will be back soon

Going from not flying at all to sending rockets to the moon and beyond has almost all happened during my lifetime. But military aircraft has largely been developed secretely surrounded by mystery, myths of Alliens, and unbelievable achievement. To be able to see examples of this development upclose and touchable is to me more exciting, thrilling, and inspiring than to watch the most are out and futuristic movie about air and space travel. Anything can be done in the movies through models, art work and computers. But what you see at the Hill Air Force Base Museum WE ACTUALLY DID. To see it makes one proud to be a member of the human race. I thank the people at Hill Air Force Base for assembling such a breath-taking array of these aircrafts, and organize and maintain them for us to see that WE REALLY DID IT! (I wonder what unbelievable "marvels" are on the drawing boards or evening being flight test as we marvel at what we see at this great museum. If you are even close the it, DON'T MISS IT!
_source.review_title: See the amazing history of American military aircraft up close and touchable

_source.comment:
My son is an airplane/military aficionado. This stop on our trip was completely for him (16). And he and my hubby loved it. My daughter (13) and I spent the time downloading photos into my laptop (we've had to do these stops before and, frankly, when you've seen one plane, you've seen them all if you're not interested in them).
Planes, planes, planes. I don't know the specific models, but the boys took lots of pictures. There aren't many places for the "significant others" to sit and wait. I think they spent about an hour and a half looking at the planes (we knew we were on a tight schedule, so they may have rushed through the museum thinking they might run out of time). The staff/volunteers seemed very knowledgable and even suggested another museum he may like. That was super helpful since I never know what to look for in these things.
We decided to wait in a room that was dark (to preserve the artifacts), cool and not as busy. Turned out it was a flight suit exhibit - those were interesting for us to look at.
Admission is free (or by donation).
_source.review_title: The boys loved it! The girls... not so much.

_source.comment: The collection of aerospace items in this facility staffed by veterans will take alot of time that could not be better spent to see. Come early in the morning to see the static displays and then the hot portion of the day visiting the interior of the two buildings.
We were there in February and walked around through several buildings inside. Just a super bunch of variety of planes in here and worth a couple of hours of your time if you are visiting the area.
_source.review_title: Pretty interesting and mostly indoors, nice!

_source.comment:
We live near this museum and I have been taking my children (ages 7 and 5) here regularly for several years. This museum has two large hangars full of airplanes representing the history of flight from the Wright brothers to the F-16. Planes from all of the major wars in the last century are represented. There is also a large yard in front with many more planes to see up close. My grandpa piloted a B-24 in WWII and I like seeing that plane with my kids and sharing their history with them. The volunteers are friendly and knowledgeable. Best of all, there is no charge to enjoy the museum, though donations are gratefully accepted.
There is an Education Room in the back hangar where kids can play with science toys. It isn't open all the time, so check in advance if you want to be sure it will be open for your visit. For younger kids there are traditional toys and for older kids (and adults) there are flight simulators and computers. Once last summer a volunteer helped helped us make paper rockets that we then took outside and shot into the air.
Tripadvisor's Ogden address for this attraction threw me off a little. This museum is inside Hill Air Force Base, just west of I-15 near Roy, a smaller city just south of Ogden. You can easily see this museum from the freeway, especially if you are travelling from the south.

Hill Air Force Base Museum is conveniently located on Interstate 15 about 35 miles north of Salt Lake City. For anyone interested in military aircraft, the Museum displays a very large collection of U.S. Air Force aircraft from about 1940 to 2000.
The collection includes famous aircraft from the Cold War period including the B-52, B-47, F-102, F-4, C-124, and many others. The collection includes notable World War II aircraft inculding the B-29, B-24, B-17, P-40, P-51, P-47, and P-38.
The large aircraft are displayed outdooors, where they unfortunately show the effects of weather. Smaller and fully-restored aircraft are displayed inside two large air-conditioned buildings where they are well protected but unfortunately parked so close to one another it is sometimes difficult to fully appreciate the aircraft. There are a large number of displays of missles, aircraft engine cut-aways, etc. Admission is free. Access to the Museum is very convenient, because it is adjacent to, but not enclosed in, the active Air Force Base, so there are no difficult admission procedures.
One of the most interesting displays focuses on women pilots who served in World War II, mainly ferrying aircraft. I was surprised and saddened to learn that many of these women faced a great deal of hostility from male fliers, mechanics, etc. It is sad that people had time for that pettiness while trying to fight such a major war.
_source.review_title: very extensive Air Force museum north of Salt lake City

_source.comment:
My husband and I took our 9 year old son here on September 2, 2007 while en route from Brigham City to Salt Lake City. The museum is located by the Hill Air Force base. Our son is very interested in World War II and military aircraft. He very much enjoyed the museum as did myself and my husband!
This museum houses dozens of renovated military aircraft, from the Wright Flyer to WWII planes and newer jet fighters such as an F-15 and a Blackbird. There are indoor and outdoor exhibits (the larger planes are located outdoors, such as the B-52 bomber). The complete listing of aircraft is on the museum's website. Outside we also saw aircraft landing at the Air Force base which was cool.
There are informative displays about each aircraft and even a small military uniform display. Volunteers are on staff to provide insight about the various aircraft. Since my son appeared very into the museum we were given a very thorough tour of the museum by two volunteers, which we enjoyed very much and found very informative.
The museum and parking are free and open 7 days a week. I would definitely recommend this museum to military aircraft and history enthusiasts.

Not as extensive as the Air and Space Museum at Dulles airport in the DC area, but still lots of aeronautical history that has been maintained well. If you are a military airplane buff, it's worth visiting.
